article.title: Nonlinear reconstruction of redshift space distortions

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the cross-correlation coefficient tell us about the reconstructed density field in redshift space?
choices: It perfectly matches the linear initial conditions.
It contains no information from the linear initial conditions.
It correlates with the linear initial conditions to a much smaller scale than the original redshift space density field.
It is identical to the cross-correlation coefficient of the nonlinear density field with the linear initial conditions.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can we infer from the different correlation strengths of the reconstructed density field with the linear and nonlinear fields for different µ bins?
choices: Reconstruction performs equally well in all directions.
The reconstructed density field is a perfect representation of the true density field.
The B-mode shift velocity has a negligible effect on reconstruction.
Reconstruction performs better along the k⊥ axis and the B-mode shift velocity degrades the performance along the line of sight.

multiple_choice_question.text: Why does the power spectrum amplitude ratio drop faster than the correlation coefficient on large scales?
choices: Reconstruction only recovers the cross-correlation and cannot recover the full broadband power spectrum.
Reconstruction amplifies the power spectrum on large scales.
The linear and nonlinear power spectra are identical.
The reconstructed density field contains no information about the original density field.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the formula δ₁(k) = −ik · ψ₁(k) = (1 + fμ²)δι(k) represent?
choices: The nonlinear displacement divergence in redshift space.
The linear density field in real space.
The linear displacement divergence in redshift space.
The nonlinear density field in redshift space.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can we infer from the formula v(q,t) = af Hψ(1)(q, t) + 2af Hψ(2) (q, t) +...  about the relation between Lagrangian velocity and displacement?
choices: The Lagrangian velocity is simply the Lagrangian displacement multiplied by a constant.
The Lagrangian velocity is more linear than the Lagrangian displacement.
The Lagrangian displacement is the time integral of the Lagrangian velocity.
The Lagrangian velocity cannot be expressed in terms of the Lagrangian displacement.
